post.title: Local Festivals in November
post.subtitle: Discover the cultural celebrations that make visiting in the off-season special.
post.author: Marco Bianchi
post.authorBio: A cultural journalist who documents the traditional festivals and celebrations of the Ligurian coast.

content.intro: November in Cinque Terre brings a quieter energy—but it's far from boring. Traditional festivals, food celebrations, and cultural events give visitors a glimpse into authentic village life that summer tourists never see.

sections.title: All Saints' Day (November 1)
sections.text: A national holiday when Italians visit cemeteries to honor the dead. In Cinque Terre, this is a poignant day—many families have generations buried in the tiny village cemeteries overlooking the sea. Visitors are welcome to observe, respectfully.

sections.title: Olive Harvest Season
sections.text: November marks the beginning of the olive harvest. Watch farmers collecting olives on the terraces, and look for fresh-pressed olive oil in local shops. Some agriturismi offer harvest experiences—a hands-on way to connect with the land.

sections.title: Feast of San Martino (November 11)
sections.text: This celebration marks the end of the grape harvest and the opening of new wine. In villages across Cinque Terre, locals gather to taste the season's first wines, often paired with roasted chestnuts. Ask at local wine bars about events.

sections.title: What to Expect
sections.text: Some restaurants and shops close for the season, but those that stay open welcome visitors warmly. The weather can be dramatic—storms create spectacular waves and moody skies. Bring layers, embrace the quiet, and enjoy having the villages to yourself.
